SENT.plain: Accumulating evidence from experimental and epidemiological studies suggests that vitamin D deficiency might be a causal risk factor for cancer and therewith associated mortality

We performed a systematic review in Medline up to February 2012 to identify prospective studies on 25-hydroxyvitamin D (25[OH]D) and cancer mortality as well as on 25(OH)D and survival in cancer patients
Our search retrieved 13 studies on cancer-specific mortality and 20 studies on overall mortality in cancer patients
Data on 25(OH)D and cancer mortality were mainly derived from general populations
The results were inconsistent and yielded either no, inverse or positive associations
By contrast, the majority of studies in cancer patients showed that patients with higher 25(OH)D levels had a decreased risk of mortality
This relationship was particularly evident in cohorts of colorectal cancer patients
In contrast, there was no indication for increased mortality risk with higher vitamin D levels in any cancer cohort
In conclusion, the relationship of vitamin D status and cancerspecific mortality is still unclear and warrants further studies
Our results provide a strong rationale to perform prospective randomized controlled studies to document a potential effect of vitamin D supplementation on survival in cancer patients
